docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Louis S. Goodman, a renowned pharmacologist, a discoverer of the first effective anticancer chemotherapy and a creator of a textbook used by generations of doctors, died at his home in Salt Lake City on Nov. 19. He was 94 and had taught for many years at the University of Utah. In Salt Lake City in 1946, Dr. Goodman also supervised a daring experiment in which his team totally and temporarily paralyzed a colleague with curare, the muscle relaxant that South American Indians used as a poison. Until then, few doctors had used curare in patients for fear that it produced permanent paralysis. That and other experiments helped widen use of curare and similar drugs, greatly increasing the safety of anesthesia and allowing surgeons to develop new operations.

docs.lead_paragraph: Of the 80,000 or so chemicals that go into the products of daily life, the vast majority have never been thoroughly tested for harmful effects. The traditional approach to such testing, exposing laboratory animals to the chemical, is slow, expensive and attacked by animal rights groups. And what happens in animals doesn't always correspond with what happens in people. But hope is growing among scientists that a new approach -- studying genes -- could offer a faster, cheaper and more accurate way to test drugs, chemicals, food additives and cosmetics.

headline.main: DNA Chip May Help Usher In a New Era of Product Testing

docs.abstract: New type of toxicology testing, called toxicogenomics, studies genes to test for harmful effects in drugs, chemicals, food additives and cosmetics; technique involves exposing animals or cells in test tube to chemical; special chips, known as DNA chips, are used to see which genes are turned on or off as animal or cells react; this pattern of gene activity, at least in theory, should indicate whether chemical is toxic, much as DNA fingerprints are used to judge guilt or innocence of criminal suspects; technique is still in early experimental stage, but it offers hope of faster, cheaper and more accurate way to test for toxicity; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: DRUG and alcohol abuse ''by our own children'' has reached an ''almost epidemic state,'' Dr. Charles W. Fowler, the superintendent of Hewlett-Woodmere public schools, said in a letter to parents announcing a town meeting to discuss what could be done about the problem. Nearly 600 parents responded, so many in fact that the Nov. 15 meeting had to be moved from the Hewlett High School auditorium to the gymnasium. Dr. Fowler called the gathering ''the largest turnout in the school's history.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Stocks resumed their broad slide yesterday in a session that experienced sudden shifts in response to the legal battle over Florida's presidential vote and felt the weight of concerns about the profits of technology companies. The Nasdaq composite index tumbled 116.11 points, or 4 percent, to 2,755.34, its fifth consecutive loss and the 11th in 13 trading sessions since the Friday before Election Day. The latest Nasdaq decline swelled its loss for the year to 32.3 percent. It has plunged 45.4 percent from its record high on March 10.

docs.lead_paragraph: Maria de Jesus Viana may have saved only a dollar, but the discovery she made could eventually be worth much, much more. When Ms. Viana went to the doctor recently complaining of shortness of breath, her physician prescribed the asthma medicine salbutamol sulfate. What happened next was something that had never happened to her, or millions of Brazilians like her, before.

headline.main: Explosion of Generics About to Occur in Brazil

docs.abstract: Generic drugs are beginning to catch on in Brazil, where brand-name medicines have long held sway; nine generics are planned under new joint venture between Teva of Israel, largest generic manufacturer in the world, and Brazil's Laboratorios Biosintetica; photo (M)
